guide.conclusion: This project first appeared in CRAFT Volume 10, pages 119-122.

flags.title: From CRAFT
flags.text: This project first appeared on the pages of CRAFT or on Craftzine.

guide.introduction:
There are countless ways to show your personality through crafts. It’s easy to create beyond the traditional and come up with something truly unique. Instead of sewing a bag that can simply carry your stuff, you can come up with something that reflects who you are. This guitar bag does just that. Not only does it shout to the world that you have rocking sewing skills, it also shows that you rock, be it as a genuine or wannabe rock star.

With an endless array of colors to choose from, you can even express what kind of music you’re into. Whether you’re a punk princess or a hardcore metal artist, you can sport this bag and be the envy of everyone. After all, everyone can relate to loving music.
guide.introduction_rendered:
There are countless ways to show your personality through crafts. It’s easy to create beyond the traditional and come up with something truly unique. Instead of sewing a bag that can simply carry your stuff, you can come up with something that reflects who you are. This guitar bag does just that. Not only does it shout to the world that you have rocking sewing skills, it also shows that you rock, be it as a genuine or wannabe rock star.

With an endless array of colors to choose from, you can even express what kind of music you’re into. Whether you’re a punk princess or a hardcore metal artist, you can sport this bag and be the envy of everyone. After all, everyone can relate to loving music.

Relevant parts
  • Fabric
  • Buttons
  • Thread
  • Black wedding
  • Strap adjuster
  • Bias tape
  • Interfacing
  • Paper
  • Pins
  • Tailor's chalk
  • Velcro
Tools
  • Computer
  • Measuring tape
  • Printer
  • Scissors
  • Sewing machine

parts.notes: in 2 or 3 colors, for the body, pickguard, and lining, metallic silver fabric for the bridge and input jack.
for the tone and volume controls. They should match the pickguard fabric.
silver embroidery thread for the screws
or the single-coil pickups, the color should match your fabric for the pickguard.

lines.text: Find and print an image of a Fender Stratocaster onto legal-sized paper. Don’t include the fretboard. You’ll use only the body shape as your pattern.
lines.text_raw: Find and print an image of a Fender Stratocaster onto legal-sized paper. Don’t include the fretboard. You’ll use only the body shape as your pattern.

lines.text: Cut out the guitar shape, and then trace the image onto your fabric. Make sure that your guitar body, lining, and pickguard pieces mirror each other.
lines.text_raw: Cut out the guitar shape, and then trace the image onto your fabric. Make sure that your guitar body, lining, and pickguard pieces mirror each other.

lines.text: Mark the highest points of the body and lining pieces. These are the highest points of the curved horns on each side of the fretboard of a real Fender Strat.
lines.text_raw: Mark the highest points of the body and lining pieces. These are the highest points of the curved horns on each side of the fretboard of a real Fender Strat.

steps.title: Create the bridge and input jack.

lines.text: Cut a small piece of interfacing, approximately 2"×1". Cover this with metallic silver fabric, and pin. Don’t sew it! This will be your bridge, and you’ll sew it directly onto the bag.
lines.text_raw: Cut a small piece of interfacing, approximately 2"×1". Cover this with metallic silver fabric, and pin. Don’t sew it! This will be your bridge, and you’ll sew it directly onto the bag.

lines.text: Draw a teardrop pattern on 2 small pieces of the same silver fabric, similar in size to your bridge. Sew, right sides together, and turn inside out. This teardrop piece will be your input jack.
lines.text_raw: Draw a teardrop pattern on 2 small pieces of the same silver fabric, similar in size to your bridge. Sew, right sides together, and turn inside out. This teardrop piece will be your input jack.

lines.text: Set your bridge and input jack aside.
lines.text_raw: Set your bridge and input jack aside.

steps.title: Sew the pickguard, bridge, and input jack onto the guitar.

lines.text: Pin your pickguard pieces, right sides together. Sew all the way around, leaving a 2" opening for turning it inside out. Before turning the pickguard inside out, clip or cut around it. This will nicely define the curves. Then turn it right side out.
lines.text_raw: Pin your pickguard pieces, right sides together. Sew all the way around, leaving a 2" opening for turning it inside out. Before turning the pickguard inside out, clip or cut around it. This will nicely define the curves. Then turn it right side out.

lines.text: Position your pickguard on the body and sew, using the image you printed for reference.
lines.text_raw: Position your pickguard on the body and sew, using the image you printed for reference.

lines.text: To position the bridge and input jack, again refer to the image you printed out. Sew them onto the body, using matching thread.
lines.text_raw: To position the bridge and input jack, again refer to the image you printed out. Sew them onto the body, using matching thread.

lines.text: Cut three 2" strips of bias tape. Position them on your pickguard. They should be aligned to the bridge, except that the bias strip near the bridge should be slanting. Again, use your printed image as a reference. Sew the bias strips onto your pickguard.
lines.text_raw: Cut three 2" strips of bias tape. Position them on your pickguard. They should be aligned to the bridge, except that the bias strip near the bridge should be slanting. Again, use your printed image as a reference. Sew the bias strips onto your pickguard.

lines.text: Using tailor’s chalk, mark 6 points on these bias tape strips and on your bridge. These points should also align; they’re the pickup pole pieces and the bridge saddles for each string. Mark another 2 points on the opposite ends of your input jack, and the points near the edge of the pickguard where there are more screws.
lines.text_raw: Using tailor’s chalk, mark 6 points on these bias tape strips and on your bridge. These points should also align; they’re the pickup pole pieces and the bridge saddles for each string. Mark another 2 points on the opposite ends of your input jack, and the points near the edge of the pickguard where there are more screws.

lines.text: Embroider these points with silver thread, using a backstitch or French knots.
lines.text_raw: Embroider these points with silver thread, using a backstitch or French knots.

steps.title: Add tone and volume controls and finish the body.

lines.text: Sew the 3 buttons onto your pickguard as the tone and volume controls.
lines.text_raw: Sew the 3 buttons onto your pickguard as the tone and volume controls.

lines.text: Sew the body pieces, right sides together, beginning and ending at the highest points that you marked. Turn the body inside out.
lines.text_raw: Sew the body pieces, right sides together, beginning and ending at the highest points that you marked. Turn the body inside out.

steps.title: Sew the lining and the strap.

lines.text: Sew the lining, but leave a gap at the bottom. Don’t turn it inside out. Before sewing the lining, you may choose to add velcro or a magnetic snap for the bag closure.
lines.text_raw: Sew the lining, but leave a gap at the bottom. Don’t turn it inside out. Before sewing the lining, you may choose to add velcro or a magnetic snap for the bag closure.

lines.text: Insert the body inside the lining. Then sew the mouth of your bag by sewing the lining to the body.
lines.text_raw: Insert the body inside the lining. Then sew the mouth of your bag by sewing the lining to the body.

lines.text: Turn the bag inside out through the gap in the lining, and topstitch the opening of your bag.
lines.text_raw: Turn the bag inside out through the gap in the lining, and topstitch the opening of your bag.

lines.text: Take a 1"-wide piece of black webbing and fashion it with an adjuster to use as a strap. Sew the ends of the webbing to the back of the bag’s top horns.
lines.text_raw: Take a 1"-wide piece of black webbing and fashion it with an adjuster to use as a strap. Sew the ends of the webbing to the back of the bag’s top horns.

lines.text: Sew up the gap in the lining. Attach your favorite band buttons to the strap, and you’re ready to rock!
lines.text_raw: Sew up the gap in the lining. Attach your favorite band buttons to the strap, and you’re ready to rock!

lines.text: There are other ways to create your own guitar bag, and I’m sure you’ll come up with great ideas that speak to your own uniqueness. Add a whammy bar or real guitar strap!
lines.text_raw: There are other ways to create your own guitar bag, and I’m sure you’ll come up with great ideas that speak to your own uniqueness. Add a whammy bar or real guitar strap!

lines.text: Instead of sewing the individual elements, one alternative is to print an image of a guitar on fabric, then stitch it up to a coordinating backside (or maybe you’ll print the back of a guitar for that piece, too).
lines.text_raw: Instead of sewing the individual elements, one alternative is to print an image of a guitar on fabric, then stitch it up to a coordinating backside (or maybe you’ll print the back of a guitar for that piece, too).

guide.summary: Show the world you rock with this cool and easy-to-make bag.
guide.title: Guitar Bag
